We had booked his tuk tuk services from 8th to 11th febNow coming to SarnathWe visited Sarnath on 9th and 11th, What an amazing place for my daughter to know about Indian history and Buddha;s histroryWe took help of a local guide which Raj arranged for Rs 200 and he joined us to all the nearby places in Sarnath(Dhamek Stupa,Thai temple,Chaukand stupa)I also bought the Tibetian Music Bowl and my wife bought some lovely handbags at a good bargained price( as opposed to normal trend of getting commision from them) which was helped by Raj . More than just a driver Raj was a great tourist guide too showing a  lot of temples like the Mani temple , Baba bhairav temple which are not mentioned in most of the blogs.He  took us to  all the places to try the  best delicacies  that was on my list.

name: Ram Gautam
review_body: It's such a shame that tourists who visit this place without a guide will be looted. We were so excited to visit this Archaeological Buddhist site. The way of buying a ticket was either to do it online or you had to scan a QR for ticket payment. But as we were a tourist who had just arrived and we didn't have mobile data access (as Nepalese people are not allowed to buy a local sim card with a Nepalese passport, which is a shame) or UPI. So, we asked for an option but the guards suggested we pay 50-100 rupees per person extra to the local guy to enter. We didn't want to be part of this scamming technique to enter these heritage sites so we went up to cops sitting nearby to seek help as we really wanted to visit Sarnath. But, the cops sitting nearby defamed me when he got to know I was from Nepal. he not only me but my country Nepal and all the Nepalese. I cannot even publicly mention what he told me about my country Nepal. I would have beaten anyone for defaming me and my country, but as it was a policeman I didn't want any trouble during my travel with my mom. So, we decided to skip the plan of visiting Sarnath. Not only me and my mom were deprived of visiting Sarnath, but there were a few other foreign visitors from Sweden and France who faced the same problem.Even to enter the Sarnath museum there was an online system, we understand India wants to go fully digitalized. But on the monument's site, there should be the option of a ticket counter for foreign tourists who have issues buying tickets online. Tourists come to visit this beautiful country and monuments from all around the world but due to lack of access to buy the ticket they are deprived to enter the heritage sites and museums. One of the domestic tourists a young gentle guy (Arun Chauhan, who had come from Delhi) paid for our museum tickets, I appreciate his help though we couldn't visit Sarnath we could visit the Museum because of his generous act.

name: Wanderer
review_heading: 'Sarnath'- The site where Buddha preached his first sermon to his five disciples
review_body: Very peaceful historical site.... It's a must visit place if one is visiting Varanasi....Online tickets have to be booked using their website or by scanning the QR Code available there....Take the help of the tour guides( under Government of India)... However,  they will ask you to pay huge amount... bargaining the rate is absolutely possible... They will take you all around the site and will impart the historical facts to the best of their knowledge.... Must visit the adjacent museum as well which houses the half of Ashokan pillars.... Side note(Warning)-However,  I must mention about the fraud that is committed some 200-300mtrs away from the main Sarnath site.... So if you hire some cabs or other private transport,  they are gonna drop you off near the Sarnath monastery (which was built by some Thai King about 100 yrs ago).... There you will meet some wannabe tour guides who will literally force you to hire them at a paltry sum of Rs 100-200... Then they will take you around the monastery premises and the temple and will give you some basic info available easily on the wikipedia.... And then on the pretext of showing how Banarasi Sarees are weaved,  they will take you to the backside of a shop and will literally force you to buy Sarees from them... All these happened before we got to see the main Sarnath site.... they were trying to dupe us... When we enquired them about the Stupas and all, that bloke even had the audacity to tell us that the real Sarnath is a wastage of time...Thanks to the owner of a tea stall outside the monastery.... He told us everything about these frauds and was kind enough to guide us to the real site....Such a pathetic experience... I hope government authorities will take strict actions against these fraudsters....Other than this, I had an amazing experience at the Sarnath....

name: Subhash Jha
review_heading: Serene Tranquil - Relive Buddha Ashoka and their relics.
review_body: Sarnath is a place located 10 kilometres north-east of Varanasi near the confluence of the Ganges and the Varuna rivers in Uttar Pradesh. The deer park in Sarnath is wherein, circa 528 BCE, at 35 years of age, Gautama Buddha taught his first sermon after attaining enlightenment at Bodh Gaya. Buddha mentioned Sarnath as one of the four places of pilgrimage his devout followers should visit. The attractionsChaukhandi Stupa was built as a terraced temple during 7th & 8th centuries where Buddha & his first disciples met. Govardhan, the son of Raja Todar Mal, modified the stupa to its present shape by building the octagonal tower to commemorate the visit of Humayun, the Mughal ruler.The Dhamek StupaThe Dharmarajika StupaThe Ashokan pillar The ruins of the ancient Mulagandha Kuty Vihara mark the place where the Buddha spent his first rainy season.The Dharma Chakra Jina Vihar, a massive monastery and living quarters for monksThe famous Lion Capital of Ashoka, which miraculously survived its 45-foot drop to the ground (from the top of the Ashokan pillar), and became the State Emblem of India and national symbol on the flag of India. The museum also houses the original 5th-century CE sandstone sculpture of Buddha Preaching his First Sermon, as well as the Kumaradevi inscriptionTourist attractions unrelated to Buddhism and spirituality in Sarnath include the Sarnath Deer Park and Fish Canal, and the Sarnath Turtle Breeding and Rehabilitation Centre.

name: Raman G
review_heading: Do not miss. Even if you are not interested in history
review_body: This place is a must if in Varanasi.  To enjoy the full area you need 2 to 3 hours. We went around 11 in morning. On a Saturday.  Not crowded when we reached.  A free car parking opp the park where entry is free. This is the park where the first sermon was given to Buddha disciples. The original tree is not there any longer but a large tree is present from a new sampling planted.  Do take a guide when visiting this park.  A number of them hovering around the entrance. The guide will tell you to pay as ' you like '. This is true. The walk around is max 30 minutes. Get a history lesson from the guide and take pictures. The guides are experts to taking the best shots for you with the right angles. The guide is OK to take a Rs 100 to escort you. However,  the visit to the Archeological Survey of India excavation site and museum is a must must to understand the full history of Sarnath. The excavation site is about 100 mtr away from the park and the museum is beside this site. The excavation site is very well maintained and top class clean. Of course this August month visit was hot and humid. Carry your hat, cap or umbrella.  You must get a guide. The history is what makes the visit interesting. The entry fee for site and museum is rs 50 per head when paid online at ASI website.  In the museum camera are not allowed. Lockers are available to store camera and bag and mobiles. The museum is air contioned ( unlike the one on BHU ). This museum has more than 95% displays which have been excavated from sarnath site itself. The main attraction in museum is the original excavated Ashoka Pillar, the national emblem. We were really impressed with the knowledge of our guide for the 3 places visited, hire guide for museum as well. We would have spent nearly 3 hours for the visit. We did not visit the other stupa in a different park nearby ( we were tired now ). The guide we engaged , Mr Sanjay Singh 9648673225; 6394080981. He informed us that he has been reading Sarnath history for about 15 years now. Enjoy your visit. Winter months the ideal months to visit as there is outdoor walking.

name: colin h
review_body: Sarnarth was where Buddha delivered his first sermon.  By visiting (with a guide) I learnt much about Buddha (the person), Buddism and the part this site (and India) played in this religion, all of which I found very interesting.  Without a guide or a guide book you will not understand much as there are very few information boards.  The site itself is 2 complete buildings (one associated with Buddha, the other with Jainism.  The rest of the site is the ruins (and really only the foundations) of earlier temples.  As a visitor attraction, it does not have the same impact as the Taj Mahal or other palaces, forts and religious sites.  Nevertheless it is a fascinating place to go to.  We went on a hot morning and an hour was more than enough to walk to site - it is open with limited shade so be prepared with hats, umbrellas, cream and water.
